basics.name: Tanmoy Sanyal
basics.label: Scientist, Computational drug design & Structural biology

education.specialization: Graduate emphasis in Computational Science & Engineering (Parallel Computing & Numerical methods for ODEs / PDEs)

education.studyType: Masters and Bachelors of Technology (Hons.) integrated dual degree

highlights.title: Biologics Design
highlights.description: Design of peptides and antibodies for rare endocrine disorders, and SAR (structure activity relationship) analysis based on PLMs (protein language models)

highlights.title: Scientific Software development
highlights.description: Computational workflows for automating molecular model building and MD simulation of modified peptides, such as small molecule acylations or peptide-biopolymer conjugates.

work.company: Department of Bioengineering, University of California San Francisco

highlights.title: Protein structure modeling using chemical crosslinks
highlights.description: Combined Homology models + chemical-crosslinks + cryo-EM data for protein complex structure modeling; graph sampling methods to extract domain information from crosslinks. Applications include SMC and DNA helicase protein families.

highlights.title: Computational mapping of nanobody epitopes
highlights.description: Developed software to integrate chemical crosslinks with escape mutation data for protein-protein docking. Applications include epitope prediction of nanobodies on wild-type SARS-CoV-2 spike and variants.

highlights.title: Whole cell models
highlights.description: Developed Bayesian Network models to combine continuum scale (pharmacokinetic), particle scale (Brownian dynamics) and network scale (enzyme pathways) models of the pancreatic beta-cell into build a proof-of-concept multimodal digitial twin Served as software lead within the Pancreatic Beta-Cell consortium (collaborating across UCSF, USC, ShanghaiTech and HUJI)

work.company: Chemical Engineering, University of California Santa Barbara

highlights.title: Thesis
highlights.description: Next-Generation Coarse-Grained Models for Molecular Dynamics Simulations of Fluid Phase Equilibria and Protein Biophysics Using the Relative Entropy

highlights.title: Coarse-graining algorithms for bulk liquids
highlights.description: Introduced the local density potential for structurally and thermodynamically accurate coarse-grained MD simulations of liquid-liquid phase separation, which are relatively rare in the chemical engineering literature

highlights.title: Coarse-graining algorithms for protein folding
highlights.description: Developed protein backbone models for (i) template-free folding of 200+ residue coarse-grained protein domains using MD simulations, and (ii) studying self-assembly in amyloidogenic peptides

highlights.title: High Performance Computing
highlights.description: As system administrator, set up 144 core Linux (Rocks 6.2) cluster and wrote utilities for automating (i) network-attached-storage management, and (ii) conflict-free compute resource sharing between lab members.
